Campaigning for the Presidency seven years ago, Ronald Reagan called for a ''North American Compact'' to bind the United States, Canada and Mexico. Nothing came of the idea, but acid rain brings it back to mind.

The Reagan Administration was slow to acknowledge that acid rain exists, and still slower to admit that U.S. pollutants might be falling on Canada. After a joint U.S.-Canadian commission confirmed the problem last fall, Canadians hoped Mr. Reagan would act to clean it up. What his new budget proposes instead is more research.

Worse, no sooner was the budget made public than Washington signed an agreement requiring Mexico to control sulfur emissions at the new copper smelter at Nacovari, 55 miles south of the border. Uncontrolled, it would be one of the worst polluters in North America.

Let U.S. sulfur fall where it will, but let no one else's sulfur fall on the U.S. - that is the apparent policy. And that's not all. A Canadian company won the contract to build the Nacovari control unit, a plant to convert the emissions to sulfuric acid, financed by a $41 million export loan from the Canadian Government.
North American Compact? Not without the United States' cooperation.
